channel.title: Bioinformatics on Ingots of learning
channel.description: Recent content in Bioinformatics on Ingots of learning

item.title: Bioinformatics with Rosalind - RNA
item.description: This Rosalind problem deals with RNA. RNA differs slightly from DNA, in that the ribose is oxy’d instead of deoxy’d, and instead of (T)hymine is has (U)racil. The problem itself is pretty simple: Given: A DNA string t having length at most 1000 nt. Return: The transcribed RNA string of t. My answer is as follows. Note this time I load in the string from a text object instead of copying it into the program itself, and output the answer into a text file as well.

item.title: Bioinformatics with Rosalind - DNA
item.description: There’s an offshoot of data science called Bioinformatics, and it’s essentially the study of how to extract meaningful information out of genetic information. Now, this sounds super cool, so I’ve decided to learn a bit about it. To help me with this, I’ll be doing the Rosalind problems, and posting my solution here. The first problem is to do with DNA, and it’s a relatively simple one. All DNA (that I know of) is made up of four nucleotides attached in sequence, along with some deoxyribose sugars and some phosphate groups.
